3 REPORT THE STATE OF NEBRASKA, TREASURY DEPARTMENT. I Lincoln, December 1, 1912. I To His Excellency, Chester H. Aldrich, Governor of Nebraska: KSir: Pursuant to requirements of law, I have the honor to herewith present the wing report of the Department of the State Treasury for the biennium ending ember 30, 1912. SALE OF BONDS. Under the provisions of Chapter 127, of the Laws of Nebraska, 1911, and upon the order of the Board of Educational Lands and Funds this department has offered for sale and sold bonds of other States held as security for the investment of the various educational trust funds of this state to the amount of $1,017,000.00. On the bonds bo sold the State has received a premium of $8,418.98, which amount has been credited to the various temporary educational funds. The proceeds of the bonds sold has upon the order of the Board of Educational Lands and Funds been re-invested in bonds issued within the State. By means of this re-investment the State is made the beneficiary of an increase in the rate of interest of about 93-100 per cent or approxi - mately $9,450.00 per annum. INVESTMENTS. I During the beiennium just ended there have been purchased including re-invest - ,3, bonds amounting to $2,347,484.85, all of which were issued within the State. Board of Educational Lands and Funds adopted the policy, embodied in the law rning the reinvestments of purchasing all bonds first hand, and this policy has consistently adhered to. There are now held to the credit of the various educa- J funds as shown by detailed statements following bonds in the totil sums, as us: Permanent School, $8,284,874.76; Permanent University, $145,600.00; cultural College Endowment, $511,500.00; Normal Endowment, $74,200.00. FISCAL AGENCY. I By way of further comment on the subject of bonds, I desire to say, that it is my ion that the law now in force designating a certain New York bank the State fiscal cy is detrimental to the interest of the people of the State. Under the provisions id law it is necessary for the various municipalities having outstanding bonds made ible at the fiscal agency to keep a part of the sinking funds on deposit there to meet nents as they become due from time to time. This money is sent out of the State ad of being allowed to become a part of the circulating medium at home. The icipalities lose the interest that would accrue if the money were kept on deposit ome, and this interest would in no case be less than two per cent per annum. even this is not all. The fiscal agency in addition to giving nothing for the use of

4 REPORT OF THE the Money makes a per centum charge on all bond payments, which charge the munici - palities have to pay (or the luxury of having a fiscal agency in New York. Besides, as the State is now the holder of bonds issued within the State to the amount of $6,053,874.76, and as the amount of such investments will increase from year to year it would be a decided advantage to have the bonds made payable at the office of the State Treasurer. As it is now a number of the bonds held are made payable at some local bank, others at the office of some County Treasurer. This makes it necessary for the State to assume the risk of forwarding the bonds to the place designated for payment, and though no loss in transit has been sustained up to this time, it could happen, and through the Iocs of such valuable matter in transit the State would be put to great inconvenience. And too, where bonds are made payable at some local place the State is frequently charged exchange on remittances made in payment. These exchange items amount to a considerable sum in a year, and are a loss to the State. It can not consistently be urged that bond buyers outside of the State would consider our bonds any less desir - able because of being made payable at the State Treasurer's office in place of NewYork, since the fiscal agency is a bank and is under no bond to anyone, while the State Treasurer is under a bond of $1,000,000.00, and back of him stands the credit of the entire State of Nebraska. E; is my opinion that the law should be amended in such a way that this money be kept at home where the people of the State could benefit by its use, and to that would suggest that the State Treasury could be designated as the State fiscal REMITTANCES BY COUNTY TREASURERS. During the fall months of the two years last past the State Treasury has been hard pressed for money with which to pay general fund warrants, and this statement is emphasized by the additional statement that general fund warrants to the amount of $147.337.9 1 are at this time carried as an investment to the credit of the Permanent School Fund. This condition is due partly to the narrow margin between the biennial appropriations last made and the estimated income. It is also partly due to the fact that a large number of the County Treasurers throughout the State have been in the habit of holding State Funds in their hands for long periods of time when, if they were .paid over to the State Treasurer as collected they would perhaps, relieve him of the embarrassment of momentarily expecting to be compelled to register State warrants, and also of the embarrassment of asking and even demanding that the funds be paid over to him. It is my belief that the law could with profit be amended so as to require that County Treasurers should pay over to the State Treasurer all State funds in their hands not later than the tenth day of the month following that in which they were collected. In view of the fact that a number of County Treasurers have been in the habit of making such monthly payments there can be no valid reason why the practice could not be general and uniform. EDUCATIONAL LANDS AND FUNDS. KI wish to suggest and recommend that the Educational Lands of the State be back, on sale, and I give yon the following figures for your consideration. These es are based on the last biennial report and the collections of the last two years. K There are 1,714,600 acres which bring in an income to the State School Fund of ,310.00 for the biennium. This amounts to 4} per cent on a $2.18 land valuation. Id the lands be sold at the minimum price of $7.00 per acre (and to my mind this

STATE TREASURER 5 Phey would sell for) this would amount to $11,998,000.00. Figuring this 1} per cent, this would bring into the State over $1,000,000.00 in two years, ■e times greater than the amount now received. The appraisements for is are made by the several County Boards of the State, and of course the :s are very low and therefore the State gets but a very small return. I In addition to the large increase of revenue which would be received should this be sold and the money invested in bonds, the lands would then become ta table, the state, county, and school district would receive their pro-rata of taxes levied ime, and the man who purchases the land would be much better satisfied than he under the lease, and the necessity of County Boards making appraisements for I purposes would be eliminated. I have given these figures based on a 4J per cent rate, which is the minimum rate, while as a matter of fact, all lands sold, are sold on a 5 per cent basis, and the purchasers are given twenty years in which to pay the same, and these contracts are as good or better than any bond, as the title is held in the State until such time as the full amount is paid up. If this was figured on a 5 per cent rate, it would add $1 10,000.00 during each biennium, and should the lands be sold, it would relieve the State Board of a great deal of annoyance and expense in adjusting these different lease valuations. KThe foregoing, together with the following summaries and statements, are respect - submitted. WALTER A. GEORGE,
